*[Bug 18740] txtProgressBar should output to`stderr` through `message(..., appendLF = FALSE)`?*
<https://bugs.r-project.org/show_bug.cgi?id=18740>

Tomas Kalibera (<mailto:tomas.kalibera@gmail.com|tomas.kalibera@gmail.com>) changed:

           What    |Removed                     |Added
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
                 CC|                            |tomas.kalibera@gmail.com
         Resolution|---                         |Works as documented
             Status|UNCONFIRMED                 |CLOSED

--- Comment #1 from Tomas Kalibera (<mailto:tomas.kalibera@gmail.com|tomas.kalibera@gmail.com>) ---
I am afraid this really has to be solved in the packages, that is in the code
that decided to show the progress bars, and the control ideally would propagate
all the way to the user, who should be able to at least disable or enable
progress bars in different parts of code. txtProgressBar() is just a function
to display the progress bar, and it does that, and it allows to send the output
to a given file (including to standard error).

When/whether/where to show a progress bar is a matter of opinion and depends on
the specific situation. Typically, one would only display a progress bar when
interactive. But, not always only then, some progress bars may be useful even
in non-interactive output to make it easier to diagnose where things got
stuck/broke/etc. Even the output of a non-interactive process may be
interactively monitored. Standard error and standard output use different
buffering on some systems. When it is important to relate the progress to some
other information printed by the program, it may be useful to have it in
standard output - to give a better approximation of the ordering of things that
happened. Also, some systems might interpret any output to standard error as an
indication of an error.

So, I think the defaults used by txtProgressBar() are not unreasonable, and
they are documented, which is another reason why they shouldn't be changed.

text:
*[Bug 17744] pkg-config file should not contain user's LDFLAGS*
<https://bugs.r-project.org/show_bug.cgi?id=17744>

Tomas Kalibera (<mailto:tomas.kalibera@gmail.com|tomas.kalibera@gmail.com>) changed:

           What    |Removed                     |Added
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
                 CC|                            |tomas.kalibera@gmail.com

--- Comment #1 from Tomas Kalibera (<mailto:tomas.kalibera@gmail.com|tomas.kalibera@gmail.com>) ---
R has been designed to use the environment variable LDFLAGS as described in the
R Installation and Administration Manual
(<https://cran.r-project.org/doc/manuals/r-release/R-admin.html>). 

In short, LDFLAGS can be used to specify library locations using -L, and other
options to the linker - the idea is that one uses it when one has a
non-standard library location, uses a non-standard compiler, etc. The library
locations specified this way are automatically picked up and become part of
LD_LIBRARY_PATH when R is started - so become hard-coded in the installation of
R. It is hence natural that they are also used when linking the R library, even
via the .pc file, with such installation of R. With this design, it cannot be
expected that such installation of R would work without the libraries specified
in LDFLAGS.

I think this was a valid design decision (and at least not obviously badly
wrong), and this design has been in use for many years - changing it now could
break things for system administrators, maintainers of software distributions,
some users, etc.

If this design doesn't fit well to some software distribution, I think it is
best to patch it there by the distribution maintainers, who know best what they
need in their distribution. What we can provide is documented, stable (yet
maybe not ideal for everyone) behavior. So, I suggest you keep patching it
downstream to suit your needs.

--- Comment #10 from Thomas Soeiro (<mailto:Thomas.SOEIRO@ap-hm.fr|Thomas.SOEIRO@ap-hm.fr>) ---
In response to comment 9.

> I think what you want is effectively
> 
```
cbind(coefficients(summary(fit)), confint(fit)) |> as.data.frame()
```

This returns:

```
fit <- lm(breaks ~ wool * tension, warpbreaks)

cbind(coefficients(summary(fit)), confint(fit)) |> as.data.frame()

#                 Estimate Std. Error   t value     Pr(>|t|)      2.5 %    
97.5 %
# (Intercept)     44.55556   3.646761 12.217842 2.425903e-16  37.223250 
51.887861
# woolB          -16.33333   5.157299 -3.167032 2.676803e-03 -26.702779 
-5.963888
# tensionM       -20.55556   5.157299 -3.985721 2.280796e-04 -30.925001
-10.186110
# tensionH       -20.00000   5.157299 -3.877999 3.199282e-04 -30.369445 
-9.630555
# woolB:tensionM  21.11111   7.293523  2.894501 5.698287e-03   6.446501 
35.775721
# woolB:tensionH  10.55556   7.293523  1.447251 1.543266e-01  -4.109055 
25.220166
```

So it typically still requires to turn the row names to a column and set
syntactic names, e.g. for plotting a forest plot. Not difficult, but a helper
would be nice. 

> Wouldn't it be simpler to add an option to summary() to include the confidence intervals?

I like this proposal. What about

```
fit |>
    summary(<http://conf.int|conf.int> = 0.95) |> # return 95% confidence interval
    coef(data.frame = TRUE) # return a data frame with syntactic names and
terms as a column
```

?

Happy to provide a patch if R-core is interested!

*[Bug 17220] Optional ranges in chartr*
<https://bugs.r-project.org/show_bug.cgi?id=17220>

Tomas Kalibera (<mailto:tomas.kalibera@gmail.com|tomas.kalibera@gmail.com>) changed:

           What    |Removed                     |Added
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
             Status|UNCONFIRMED                 |CONFIRMED
                 CC|                            |tomas.kalibera@gmail.com
     Ever confirmed|0                           |1

--- Comment #1 from Tomas Kalibera (<mailto:tomas.kalibera@gmail.com|tomas.kalibera@gmail.com>) ---
As you found out, literal "-" can be first or last in "new" and "old". It is
not explicitly documented to be supported, but we could document it, as it is
the usual behavior in other software and seems intuitive.

So, one could specify ranges and at the same time translate from "-" or to "-".
Having "-" multiple times in "old" doesn't makes sense, but one might want it
in "new" to translate multiple characters to "-". This way, only two different
characters could be translated to "-", not more.

Out of curiosity, what is your use case? Wouldn't this be enough?

I don't think it is possible to introduce support for escaping "-" without
breaking back-compatibility, I think we shouldn't do that.

We could add an argument that would allow disabling character ranges (probably
in both "old" and "new" together for simplicity, even though technically it is
not needed for "old"). That would allow translating more than 2 characters to
"-", but on the other hand, indeed, without using any ranges, if needed.

text:
*[Bug 17744] pkg-config file should not contain user's LDFLAGS*
<https://bugs.r-project.org/show_bug.cgi?id=17744>

--- Comment #2 from Michael Orlitzky (<mailto:michael@orlitzky.com|michael@orlitzky.com>) ---
(In reply to Tomas Kalibera from comment #1)
In the simplest case, the linker used to build R may not be the one used to
build the program that is linking against libr. The -L and -l flags are
standard,

<https://pubs.opengroup.org/onlinepubs/9799919799/utilities/c17.html>

but many other flags are specific to a certain linker. If you record any
non-portable flags in pkg-config, then using another linker to link against
libr becomes impossible.

Picking a random example from the man pages...

  $ ld.lld --call-graph-profile-sort=hfsort

works, but

  $ ld.bfd --call-graph-profile-sort=hfsort
  ld.bfd: unrecognized option '--call-graph-profile-sort=hfsort'
  ld.bfd: use the --help option for usage information

Unless you are very careful about what you add to LD_LIBRARY_PATH, I would be
wary of creating a security issue by making it possible to load code from a
directory that other people can write to. I can $(mktemp) securely, build some
library there, and then link R against it. If I install the library and reboot,
will R try to load code from the old, now world-writable path that is visible
in the .pc file? (This is just a variation on the old PATH="." issue.)
